4fiyCRB1gi11Rev9fHfBMQ.text: We were excited to come upon this place and even more excited when the hostess confirmed that they had availability for the meal that they call "Sunday Roast." ("Sunday what?" we must have asked her a thousand times... one of many comical communication challenges we had with Londoners, despite ostensibly speaking the same language.) She led us upstairs and wow, the place is beautiful. I mean, the view of St. Paul's alone... but it's pretty snazzy even without that. The service throughout was friendly and efficient.However, I did not like the food. We started with short-rib croquettes, which were very dry and bland. I then had the sea trout starter, which was fine and perhaps the best thing of the meal. My St. Louis ribs, though, were basically inedible, with very, very little meat to consume. The dessert was pretty good, but I felt that the star of the show was a miss. I wouldn't return.

9l47tzl-2jU-zVMdqGADzw.text: Went to Barbecoa yesterday. Got a seat next to the window. The restaurant is **huge**, probably over 200 seats. Pretty loud, but not unbearably so.The pit beef dish was absolutely divine :)

photos.caption: Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Pit beef with broccoli side dish
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Pit beef
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. First floor entrance

n7Kx1YdhD59rnvvSlUc2Iw.text: Reception staff were a bit much. You're meant to check in with them downstairs but we didn't know that and we had a reservation so we just proceeded upstairs. That didn't go over well with the reception staff and they expressed their displeasure.The staff at St. Paul's will want to ensure that they are behaving themselves as the resto is close enough to discern otherwise.The resto is loud and large. Fancy-schmancy. Dense with beautiful people. Expensive, but not out of all proportion. A very nice Sangiovese was £8.50. A specialty cocktail called the Club Fizz (£5) was light and refreshing. The lamb shoulder (£22) was tender and flavourful as was the pit beef (£22). The Szechuan calamari appetizer with yuzu mayo was a favoured share. Sourdough bread came with veal butter (£5). I had a plain garden salad that I quite enjoyed (£3). Two of our party each ordered the mac and cheese (£7). They automatically add a service charge of %12.5. I don't care how they describe it on the bill, there's nothing "discretionary" about it.This was my first Jamie Oliver resto. It was fine for what it was. Not sure that I fell in love with the brand enough to go out of my way to go to another.

i5iWgJHuEwHuaibW8Yd2AQ.text: Met a couple of friends I hadn't seen in years here last weekend and it was very swanky indeed! From the moment Mr Debs and myself walked in downstairs, we could see we were in a rather fancy place. I mean, an actual reception area for a restaurant? Colour me impressed! We headed upstairs to wait for the rest of our guests and ordered a couple of schooners of the Organic Hells Lager which was very nice. I was really intrigued by the veal butter and so ordered the sourdough to start, which we shared - the bread was really tasty and the butter just set it off perfectly. I then went for the pit beef (I'm blaming the amount of Man V Food we'd been watching beforehand on the fact I was desperate for it) and it was delicious! Really tender and flavourful, and the lettuce on the side with bacon and shallot crumble was tasty as well.Staff were impeccable the whole night - attentive without being overbearing and the restaurant itself is gorgeous. Very sleek decor and it certainly feels upmarket. As it's right next to St Paul's Cathedral, the view you get of said cathedral is utterly amazing.The only thing I guess I would grumble about would be the price - but I suppose for the location, the atmosphere and the service it's to be expected! For a fancy dinner out in London, it's pretty ideal.

photos.caption: Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Rump steak
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Pit beef

DEA3LSwRVM6U502_g-oEBQ.text: Having walked past Jamie Oliver's Barbecoa a few times and stopping by to try and get the pork belly, which I haven't managed to secure yet as it seems extremely popular with the locals,you could imagine the excitement and joy I had when I was able to get it today.I went for the Pork Belly hotbox, which comes with a selection of beans in sauce, slow cooked pork belly and a rather posh take on coleslaw. Wraps and salad boxes are also available, however, today I felt the urge to treat myself, it was payday yesterday after all.I was delighted when the friendly member of staff handed over my food, a little less delighted when it felt very light, but happily made my way off and back to the office. I got settled in and opened up the box, taking a snap of my food for yelp of course, and was pretty happy with what lay in front of me. The coleslaw looked great, fresh and not too covered in mayonnaise, the beans and sauce smelt lovely and the generous pork belly cut looked like it had been slow cooked beyond perfection. I got stuck in and, to my disappointment, there was no crackling on the pork belly, however, what it lacked in crackling it more than made up for in flavour and taste. Coming in at around £6 for a lunch its not the cheapest option out there nor the most expensive and my only word of advice is, if you're starving and looking for a fulling lunch this may not be for you. If you are after a lovely lunch time treat, and saving room for dinner, then you're definitely in good company with this meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly hot box... Plus home made style lemonade
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom

kXrCEAPHvJkKp5CrtQKBwA.text: H & I met up with my niece & boyfriend for dinner at this Jamie Oliver restaurant. Since we were early we headed to the bar for a cocktail. They have a nice selection of cocktails, Jessica Rabbit anyone? This concoction includes vanilla vodka, strawberry puree, elderflower, lime & proseco. Yum-um! H had his usual martini & we had fun watching the mixologist making a stirred martini. Once everyone arrived we were seated by the wall of windows & the open kitchen. My niece insisted we start with the Devil's Cornbread. Being from the south I had my doubts. JO is pretty daring adding this to his menu. But oh my! Served in an iron skillet, the cornbread was light & airy. They top it with cheddar & 'nduja. Yes, yes the devil had his hand in this sinfully delicious bread. Very highly recommended starter. For our main course H & I opted for the Chateaubriand for Two (which could feed 4) topped with truffle butter. I thought it would be hard to top the Devil's Cornbread but this steak hit my top 5 best. Cooked to perfection, you could tell this was a very choice cut of beef. Really, no need for any sauce or butter. The natural flavor of the beef was outstanding & the texture perfect. I know we had sides but for the life of me I can not remember what we had. But the choices are unique like roasted pumpkin, beef dripping chips & gruyere-truffle mac & cheese.The dining area is gorgeous. Modern, warm colors with gold. The layout of the restaurant had a nice flow & with all of the windows seems much larger. The service was exceptional. Really love this place & had a wonderful evening!

Whu-hRgAL26GJCXEiZhF5g.text: Sadly, I have to give Barbecoa three stars despite exceptional food.  My friend and I were excited to dine at a Jamie Oliver restaurant while in London. We started with the trout which was a light yet tasty appetizer.  She has the fillet and I had the pit beef. Both were wonderfully prepared with amazing flavor. We shared the truffled Mac and Cheese and Devil's Cornbread. Very nice accompaniments for our beef dishes. The food was everything we had hoped it would be.  However, the service was lacking.  When we arrived for our six o'clock reservation, the restaurant was not busy and our server was attentive and the timing of cocktails and our starter was perfect. The restaurant started to get busy and the attentiveness decreased dramatically.  Our entrees were served with only slight delay but then we were forgotten. It took quite a while after finishing for our plates to be cleared and then even longer to be offered dessert menus and after dinner drinks. We finally were able to order dessert and it arrived before our drinks. Eventually the wine appeared for my friend and finally my coffee arrived.  Then we were forgotten once more and we waited a very long time for our server to be close enough so that we could request our check.  So if you don't mind a very extended dinner, then give Barbecoa a try. I would not recommend it if you have plans after dinner because you will likely be very late if what I experienced is the norm and not the exception.

UyA5LZ-Q2Y48A2jMBsXHMw.text: What a view! This is Jamie Oliver's high-end steakhouse restaurant. The view of St. Paul's Cathedral is amazing! But besides that, the food is also amazing. The Devils cornbread is a must have. It comes in a cast iron skillet, baked with gooey cheese on top. It's a bit spicy, but not so much that it's overpowering. Don't be afraid of the bread with veal butter! The butter had a mild smokey flavor which pairs well with the warm bread. The filet with smoked béarnaise sauce was divine. The steak was cooked perfectly (just ask for extra sauce you'll need it!) It came with bone marrow, but it was on the side so don't fear if that's not your thing. The Mac and cheese is always a must. All around a great experience, excellent meal!

photos.caption: Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Devil's cornbread- try this!

8g4_iYRbYePZ-r1uqJT9ng.text: If you like meat, this is the place to go! You can get a rack of ribs three times bigger than your face. I had the pork belly with waffle which was delicious! The drinks are quite good as well - happy hour is from 5 to 8 pm and you can get some cocktails for 5 pounds. My favorite thing I ate at Barbecoa was the Snickersphere, which is like a snickers in a dome form. The Snickersphere was a rich chocolate exterior filled with caramel and more chocolate and topped with gold flakes. To complement the food, there is a fantastic view of St Paul's from the restaurant!

photos.caption: Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. SNICKERSPHERE
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Pork belly & waffles
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Ginormous slab of meat

US1k3ZBaWCx934R_BGuJog.text: I made a bad menu choice!My partner had a great looking steak but my rack of ribs was covered in chillis even though I asked to forgo the jalapeño pickle, and the slaw was about 50% raw onion which looks so similar to purple cabbage that it was impossible to pick out efficiently and I was still tasting it the next day. Not that I could taste much of anything as my mouth was on fire.I really wish it was compulsory to warn people about non-consensual chilli peppers so they can make a different choice.Nice view though. And other people's steaks looked nice. The side dishes were also lovely (what I could taste of them).

0T07U1tTDvlxfahcC5nPOg.text: Went to Barbecoa yesterday with my parents before watching a play. The 'Great Gatsby' feel all around the restaurant was so enchanting. For my appetiser I had a sourdough bread with Chicken Butter. I first thought it was the craziest thing ever invented. But it was really delicious. Then for my main course I had a Rump Steak. I really don't know how to describe it because it was so delicious. The meat melted in my mouth and the mushrooms on top of it were a great touch. The service was friendly, attentive and fun.To all meat lovers out there: If you like meat, I would definitely recommend this restaurant.

TY-87sMhTArTJz2KlKWLEQ.text: Outstanding service and and great view of St. Paul's cathedral but the main course was an absolute disaster. The wagyu burger wasn't available so we got the substitute - chicken sandwich. Probably the worst chicken I've ever had. Way tooo salty. Also, the steak was hard. The appetizers were great but because the main course was awful, I just don't think that $130 lunch was worth it.

wp7ZWl_MTbYR5zfpCbJBhw.text: Well...such a mixed bag here.Service was impeccable which helps it keep the 4* rating at the end of the day. The attentiveness and charming nature was really nice.For starter I had the pork ribs....my god! So much meat on the bone, insanely tender and oooooom nom nom nom nom!!!SOooooo Barbecoa is billed as one of the cities finest steak houses...so naturally I ordered steak. Went for the rib-eye medium rare and awaited a feast. What I got was a disappointed, for the price it was chewy, sinuey and edging on inedible!! The sides were lovely but the main attraction was really lacking.I will stick to gaucho who for the same price have never let me down!

XWGcAumRJxpCIvwpkXJDbA.text: This is a great location and great quality food. The location overlooks St Paul's, adding a great view to a good meal is always a winner.The service is quick and friendly.The food gets the tastebuds all a tingle, great quality meat cuts and supporting ingredients.Someone might say it is overpriced, but you are paying London prices for great quality food. If you want cheap food, Zizzi is next door.After you finished your meal, why not go to the roof terrace for great rooftop views of St Paul's.

photos.caption: Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. View from the rooftop terrace
Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Smoked ribs three ways.

c-y9_vNw3pIWo5jgoTgWsw.text: What surprised me most about this place is that it's so massive! Seemed to carry on for ages around corners as the waitress led us to the bar area to wait for our table. Still manages to keep a buzzing, friendly feel though with almost every table occupied on a Tuesday lunchtime.I went for the burger which was good though nothing to rave about - cooked a nice medium rare just as I'd asked and held its structure well (nothing worse than a soggy bun). The duck fat chips were always going to be tasty. My colleagues also seemed to enjoy the steaks though put them on a par with a Hawksmoor; these are on the pricey side as you'd expect, up to the £75 chateaubriand for two.More exciting turned out to be the starting nibbles - two rounds of pork scratchings disappeared pretty quick and don't miss the bread board. They must also have some mutant olive breeding going on given the size of the giant puglian olives on ice. Ahh that reminds me to warn you that the small open pots on the table are salt and pepper; a colleague managed to mistake these for a place to chuck his olive stones (sorry to whoever got our table next).All A-OK so far then but I was further impressed by the staff who were attentive in re-filling wine glasses (almost overly so!) and handled a party of 12 with minimal confusion and fuss. The place itself is welcoming and I loved the unique view of St Paul's from where we sat (you can ask to sit on this side in advance - would make an extra nice backdrop for a date I think). A nice choice for a spendy meal if you're after the 'busy and bustling' vibe rather than 'peacefully intimate'. Seems to be holding its own against Ramsay's (also massive) place opposite too. I'm not rushing back for the food given there's so much out there to try, but I did manage to scope out an exciting cocktail list which I'll hopefully try at a later date.

photos.caption: Photo of Barbecoa St Paul's - London, United Kingdom. Jamie's Barbecoa Burger

Ogsvqd-Q3NyhbmOz7pwTOQ.text: One of my favorites on the London trip. Fabulous ambiance. Second floor Elegant dining with a beautiful view and great food. Service was awesome! Very affordable.

C-MB9lqI4XsJIBrhS20ZaA.text: My Fiancé and I came here to celebrate our one year anniversary.I grew up in aFamily of chefs and also work in the hospitality tourism industry.  We were really excited knowing that the standards would be high but unfortunately found our experience mediocre. Our server was polite but seemed unenthusiastic. She offered no recommendations either. We started our meal with the cracklings and found it bland and unsalted. Although it came with a sauce, It still felt like it was missing salt. Of course there was noSalt or pepper on the table . The server also did not come back check to see if our meal was satisfactory.  For our main courses I had the pulled lamb and my Fiancé had the Saint Louise Rib. The pulled lamb was cooked to perfection but lacked in seasoning and flavour. I needed To ask for BBQ sauce to pull the meal together. The sides which were a parsley & lemon salad and then something that looked liked pickled veggies and minted creme fraiche were way too overpowering and rich. I also had sweet potatoes and mine were soggy,oily and tasted very rich. I also didn't like the presentation. It looked burnt and just cut up and greasy. The Rib entree was nicely cooked but again also Very rich. It seemed that the food pairings Didn't feel balanced and tastedunseasoned. The ambience was beautiful and the best part of our meal was the cocktail and the beef dripping chips. Our experience was Not what we expected and certainlyDisappointing. We've had better food and service at Chain restaurants run with high standards front and back of the house.

pwEu8hVJ4GINmCGPs5xX-A.text: We (family of four with two teens) went to Barbacoa on Thanksgiving night. The vibe is fun and energetic. The lights were low, the music pulsed in the background and there was lots of conversation in the air. Dinner was terrific. Our meat was all done just as we like it, the sides were enough to share, and the service was good without being overdone. Our waiter helped with wine selection, even bringing a bottle back that I particularly liked, so I could photograph the label. We happened to have a table directly in front of St. Paul's, so the view was amazing. Would absolutely go back.  They also offer one of the best bourbon selections in London.

dvMZm0Z1w7oLjOHEFIoJww.text: from the unfriendly/personalityLESS woman that greeted us downstairs (sunday afternoon, she was falling out of her low-cut dress) to the waiter that insisted on showing me the mistake he claimed i made ordering wine to having a family with small children sat next to us, this never to be repeated dining experience was terrible. the food was ok, not good enough to have us return, the ambience, in what is a spectacular setting, was dictated by a staff that simply didn't want to be there. being big fans of jamie and all of his restaurants that we frequent quite often, can't imagine him being associated with this place!? definitely can't see this place expanding with other locations!!!

E8EV7MRDzNiNDMouKRpE7w.text: Mixed feelings about this one. The staff can be quite unhelpful and although the maitre d had some communication equipment so should be well aware what we were waiting for (i.e. getting seated), we had to approach her. Not the best welcome but would have forgotten it quickly if they didnt try to sit us down right next to the toilets. We had a reservation a the restaurant wasnt full so really didnt understand why they thought this was the best table at the time. There were quite a few empty tables so we asked to be moved; after answering quite a sharp "Why?" question and moving twice, we managed to get a table which was great. Food was really tasty, however, my partner wasnt feeling great later in the evening. Overall, as it is quite an expensive place, we expected a better service and after feeling unwell later, we probably won't be going back. There are many places where they'll treat you nicer for far less money.

FvjMH-2hhCEjTIIKVs3icA.text: Barbecoa is OK, but a bit too pricey for what you get. First of all, we arrive right on time for our reservation and have to wait 15-20 minutes for our table to be ready. Not a huge deal, but this plus the fact that the cloakroom was full and we had to haul our winter coats across the restaurant to our table, did not exactly get things off to an amazing start. On the atmosphere, I would say that it has a great view of St. Paul's which is visible from most areas, even if you are not right next to the windows. The decor is nice, I particularly liked the plush pink seats and open kitchen. However, on a Saturday night, this is not London's most romantic atmosphere-- not a place to go to have a long conversation over your meal... its quite loud (I don't know what I was expecting for a Saturday night, maybe I'm being unfair). The service was adequate. We ordered the bread, olives, and calamari, all of which were delicious. The bread particularly was not just your average bread board, but a selection of breads from around the world, and nice sized portions for even 4 people. The olives were standard fare Jamie olives from his other restaurants, but good. The calamari was cooked perfectly, not too crunchy or chewy, not too much batter, and came with the most perfect avocado (pseudo-guacomole) side that just made it incredible. Only complaint is that the portion was not too generous. For entrees, I got the bone-in strip steak and my friend got the lamb steak. For sides, we got the mashed potatoes and a side salad. I have to say that the biggest disappointment of the night, other than the atmosphere, was my steak. Maybe my expectations were too high, but at these prices it should be near-perfect. It was extremely fatty in most places and hard to chew. Although the potatoes were amazing (cooked twice in the oven, so interesting texture) and made the steak taste better than it was. I was stuffed by that point, so I skipped on the dessert. Overall, I would go back perhaps on a less busy weeknight and would go for the fillet steak (fyi price is wrong on their online menu at the moment, I recall it being £35 instead of £30) when feeling cash flush... but I will probably not return for a long time to give them space to work the kinks out.

080mgpksSUWfh6kyI-m5lg.text: Starters (the course that comes after the bread course) are definitely more interesting than the mains, but it was the piccalilli that pulled me to the shredded pigs ear err. cheek. I had reservations. I shouldn't have. Piccalilli perfection- just the right spiciness, the right saltiness of pork shredded into a cake.The full review is here blackheathcoffeeshops.wo…

-Rncor0_5S1AYGnwT2qoqQ.text: A joint venture between someone famed for his passion for high-quality fresh ingredients (Jamie Oliver), and a New York BBQ legend (Adam Perry Lang)  what could possibly go wrong? Well, in my experience, NOTHING! Barbecoa was a splendid place to visit  right from the moment we set down on the snaking liver-pink bench seats (can you describe furniture as having an intestinal motif?) opposite a stunning view of St Paul's dome, right through to sipping on a glorious Noah's Mill bourbon. And the message of this place is: MEAT. Messrs Oliver & Lang have set the kitchen up to use as little electricity as possible, instead making use of wood & charcoal to imbue the excellent butchery with brilliant smoky flavours. A visit's not cheap mind, although not crippling if you're careful. Our lunch came to about £70: the bread selection was the most visual dish by far, with the crispy sesame flatbread giving a radar-dish feel to the arrangement. Such tasty, tasty bread. Fans of ribs will enjoy the rib starter too  a surprisingly generous portion, basted in one of Barbecoa's freshly-produced sauces. Those were some mighty fine ribs, and no mistake. For mains we enjoyed a superb burger (think Byron, but good), and a lamb chop from the specials board. I'm not someone who rhapsodises about lamb but after tasting this I could suddenly understand why people would. The wine list is encyclopaedic ranging from keenly priced to frankly, ludicrous  but the looming cathedral reminds us we're in the Square Mile, and this sort of thing shouldn't be surprising. Beer fans will be pleased to see a perfectly formed list of bottled beers (assembled by London's famed beer writer, Melissa Cole!), and bar manager Dawid Steenkamp's hand-picked whisky list is a thing of beauty.

TZxGuP46QPnQzdJjn1hD7A.text: Terrible food, but nice view of st. Pauls. I got a steak which had no flavor and was undercooked. The sides were average at best. I know England is known for having bad food, but surely you can go better than this!!!!

41zoIJ3yBLtDCEpu5NExwg.text: Went here for dinner with a friend. We had a lovely booth at the back of the restaurant which is HUGE. We had gravlax and calamari to start which were both delicious and a burger and rump steak for main. Whatever they do to the meat here works as it really was a lovely steak. The staff were lovely, wine list sufficient, bathrooms ok but a little dark ( this is important!). We had gooey chocolate tart for desert which was amazing! Overall the bill was £60 a head (with alcohol) so will reserve for a "treat." Would go here for work or with meat eating friends.

iswrLqf937z7uSs1FLuV4g.text: It's all about the view - St. Paul's Cathedral is stunning and Barbecoa's floor to ceiling windows make the most of it.  My husband had the burger - delicious - and really a mouthful - at least 5" tall!  I had the pork chop which was huge, moist and very flavorful.  No starters, no desserts but we left quite full.

VIALX96zG9RXD0KIt-K-Ow.text: This place is fantastic, a real credit to Jamie. The food was amazing and so was the service. The layout and decor is great, nice wooden furniture, amazing view of St. Paul's Cathedral. I had the pulled pork shoulder, yum!

QWYGWI1vAZq3zjYDoCZqAg.text: Even a vegan can have an excellent meal at Barbecoa.  Starting at the Bar, the Fleur Royale was delightful (Elderflower liqueur, champagne, Chambord) and the bar tenders catered to any taste.  The breadplate was varied (all vegan except the nan) and the dark bread was the most interesting.  The roasted squash salad and roaste veggie salad were excellent - fresh and tasty.  The veggie pickles as a starter were well done.  All the meat plates had by the other diners with me were well received - we ate at Barbecoa 3 times within one week, given that it was the best around and close to our hotel.  The service team was professional and attentive, and the industrial feel was warm and muted (not enought lighting, however).  The view of St. Paul's was spectacular.  Definitely worth it, and it did not feel like a celebrity chef restaurant, but more a local hit (packed each night we were there).

uCEfVCZMuhMSF07SSctOMw.text: Jamie's slightly upscale joint in New Change doesn't disappoint. The settings are relaxed and comfortable, especially if you are able to get a seat on the leather couch-style booths. Being a guy at a table full of girls is usually a good thing in my opinion...except when I get relegated to the single hard wood seat facing the rest of the gang. To top it off, Gordon Ramsey saunters in (Jamie wasn't around which meant no fantasy top chef cookoff) and sits right behind me so I couldn't even watch in awe. Ah well, if it was Heston I would have been proper pissed.Anyways, I digress. To the main point, the food that is. Get the bread...and the olives...but especially the bread. The display is innovative and entertaining as the chunks of various breads are impaled on a wooden spear in a twisted tower. The crispy slightly garlicky bread was a great starter although my favourite was the dark rye with molasses. The massive olives on ice are very mild and refreshing and enjoyable even to an olive hater like myself.The mains were satisfying although I did give into my cravings and got the burger which as juicy and large enough to meet even my American-sized demands. The other mains ordered looked just as enticing and ensured no one had food envy.As we were there for my friend's birthday, we had brought in a cake from Konditor & Cook (carrot cake...absolutely incredible...try it) and our waitress was kind enough to sneak it to the kitchen, plate it, and bring it over candles and all to the horrendous screeching we called singing. They even lent us the use of a Global knife to do the honours without any fuss at us not ordering from their dessert menu. Definitely bonus points in my book.The price is a bit on the high side as you would expect but overall a great dining experience made it good value for money.One more quick note...I will be interested to see how things change when Ramsey's new place opens up directly opposite.

ILPZpUthO2N6ZJFXfzk6Nw.text: Mmh I really don't understand the bad ratings below. This restaurant was one of my top experiences  and because of my long international business live I have huge restaurant experience. Perhaps it was because I was there on a weekday and the weren't busyOnline Booking is easy  but be aware to book months in advance for Saturday evening.The restaurant is modern and stylish but has atmosphere. The view on St. Pauls Cathedral is astonishing and they have huge windows  so from nearly every table you have a great view.The waiters are very friendly but could be a little bit more attending. But if you ask them something about the food they really can give detailed answers.The food was absolutely fantastic1. The dry-aged Rump Steak was the best I ever had in my live  a perfection! And this for a price of 18,- Pounds in the center of London  unbelievable.2. The Barbecoa-Burger  my friend said that this was his best burger he ever had  and even if I grill a fantastic Burger  I had to agree.3. Fresh baked bread  extremely good tooThis place is now on my favorite list and I will be there a regular guest.They have around the corner their own butcher  they buy the beef directly from the farmer in Scotland  best beef you can buy for absolutely good price  try it out!

TT20GFhugNGJodfrIN9IHg.text: lovely restaurant - we were seated right under the night lights on st paul's cathedral.  the food menu was mostly american and the whisky menu had a diverse offering from around the world.we had the ribs and apple/blue cheese salad for starters then pulled pork (spicy and really well seasoned!) and burger for main.  we were stuffed by the time we saw the dessert menu so we passed.  the food was surprisingly good...as american as it gets in the uk.  the service was some of the best we've experience in any country.

quI--3ch7ZwXeAzB8i6zag.text: Good location but for the cost their a re a lot better places for steak, I found nothing exciting about their steaks and if you are looking for a really good well sourced steak that would be in any meat lovers top 5 places try Hawksmoor or Goodman.

Y9XALTwoBMqYsAMFf_lj3g.text: Be prepared to pay up, above mid-price range. I would recommend the pulled pork dish. Try to get a table by the glass walls facing Snt Paul, great view esp at night.

sDtDpCed2figniEXUY5XQA.text: 'Monkey face' they call it in Nepal.A special kind of sneer.As in, your mum tells you to eat your greens, you sneer, she says..."don't give me monkey face".Anyway, monkey face is what I got when I told people I was off to Barbacoa.Maybe it was the Jamie Oliver effect. Unfair. But many people don't seem to like him.Maybe it was the city location. Unfair as you get the most resplendant views of our very own Cathedral of St Pauls.MAybe it was the reviews. There certainly have been some bad ones since it opened.Well, I wasn't paying and I was going with a great group so, with my own best monkey face..."bovvered?".Set inside a somewhat unpromising modern mall, the place itself is thoroughly modern too. Lots of sculptured iron all over the gaff and big wall to ceiling windows which, if you're seated in the right space, do give you fantastic views of Mr Wren's Crib.Very modern. Not cheap I would imagine. A cool look, if you like that sort of thing.We got a boothed table with comfy bench seats and an impossibly large leather slate menu with which I broke a glass immediately. Clumsy fool.The menu is simplicity itself. A few starters. some choices from the grill or the wood oven. And a few puddings.  But in terms of meat, it was all there. Lamb, chicken, beef, pork. You are left in no doubt this is a meat feast.Interesting stuff too. Pulled pork, pit beef, short rib, all the usual steaks, a burger. Something for the more adventurous or the complete scaredy-cat. I went sea bass ceviche followed by chateaubriand, which I was made to share with my missus.Ceviche was about average. Not enough and a little too sour, not enough balance. The missus had a crab and avacado salad. Trade descriptions issues here. One tiny cube of avacado. But I guess rather scrimp on that than the crab. It was done nicely enough (although again, she wouldn't have minded more) but each mouthful came with shell, in some cases big bits. This is just clumsy for the price. Shame.But the mains were a different story.I have to report, the chateaubriand was nothing short of sensational. Wildly seasoned on the outside, melting meat millimeters within. I don't think I've tasted much better meat anywhere. Seriously. It came with goose fat chips which were a little leathery, spinach topped with breadcrumbs which was a little bland, garlic mash which was a little too 'raw' tasting, and reasonable carrot and swede (don't know what 'clapshot' means but the hint of orange was a nice touch).But anyway. Back to the meat.Tender mouthfuls of juicy morsels just screaming to be eaten. Loads of it too. Greedy guts here hoovered up all leftovers too and can report that the filet was great.Not one of us left denying the meat had been a real experience. As I write this next day I am suffering the meat sweats along with the alcohol from decent chianti and Montbazillac (which accompanied respectful sweets ordered out of sheer greed.) Again, nothing special there. But back to the meat.Rich tender chunks of animals who must have been pampered like babies every day they were reared for my enjoyment.Atmos, buzzy. Service, efficient and friendly enough. Prices, extravagent. etc etc etc. This place gets a rather heafty four stars from me but to be clear, this is for absolutely nothing other than the completely sumptuous animal matter. The meat drags this from 2/3 stars to the heady heights. It's that good.Anyway, back to the meat........

fsXEVB70Esm_r9pc13jrqA.text: What a space! What a view! Breathtaking. The staff, nice, professional, friendly, knowledgeable. I had three starters for lunch. The scallop ceviche (gravely under seasoned), the steak tartare - delicious (ditto), the baby back ribs (dry!?). The portions are enormous, huge, too big. I saw a lot of people eating the burgers and it looked they were serving 350g patties. I think they would do well to make everything a bit smaller.

eHmQdZXJOLwVBq-xBj6qDg.text: We went here on our recent trip.  We came here because Jamie Oliver is a partner in this restaurant.  Frankly, we were left disappointed.  Maybe we were expecting too much.  The view from our table of St. Pauls was extraordinary...everything just OK.  The food was fine if spare.The real kicker was what happened at the 2 tables on either side of us.  The one table placed their order and their food arrived.  They looked at it for a bit and were just about to dive in when the waitress came by and said that the entrees weren't theirs.  They belonged to the table on the other side of us!  So, what did the waitress do?  She picked up the plates from the wrong table and put it on the correct table.  Quite honestly, the men didn't know quite what to make of it...but being the polite British men they were they said nothing.  Wouldn't have been me.  It made us wonder where our food was before it arrived at our table!  We really felt that an offer of some sort should have been given after the entrees were on the wrong table!  Who knows what germs were on that food?  And what would have happened if they had started eating the wrong food?All in all a big disappointment.

qCYY1iW44dl8rtvCBT2hiw.text: Starters (the course that comes after the bread course) are definitely more interesting than the mains, but it was the piccalilli that pulled me to the shredded pigs ear... err, cheek. I had reservations. I shouldn't have. Piccalilli perfection- just the right spiciness, the right saltiness of pork shredded into a cake.The full review is here blackheathcoffeeshops.wo…

wt_4NOgJk-MIULiRcpG9oA.text: This is the new resturant by Jamie Oliver, situated inside the one new change centre near st pauls cathedral.The views from the resrutant overlook st pauls through a wall of glass and the setting it has to say is spot-on.The menu is mostl meat which is deliberate, its a celebraion of meat. infact the only vegetarian options are starters.The food is very good the frustation is the long waiting list to get a table as without the view this would be a standard resturant.You can sit in the bar and enjoy a nice procesco cocktail or a glass of wine and im happy to say the drinks are not over priced. Bar snacks are not availabe between 3pm and 6pm which is a little annoying.Great design and good atmosphere inside so very welcoming.

NVgvicvysmim4AaDcArKjg.text: This place should be all kinds of awesome and a carnivore's dream. The butchers belonging to it downstairs is as beautiful as can be. Combine the obvious attention to detail and quality of meaty ingredients with the enviable location opposite St Pauls and the understated relaxed elegance of the dining room, and Barbecoa is looking like something really special. So what went wrong? Well, the food was very nice but not sparklingly good, and certainly not deserving of the hefty city price-tags. The baby back ribs were clumsily over-spiced and the appetiser pork scratchings rather dull and lacking in flavour. Mains-wise the beef short rib was begging for a sauce and the pork belly, though beautifully cooked, was under-seasoned. We didn't do desserts or booze apart from one glass of overpriced Malbec and still managed to spend £140 for 4. Ouch. Want ribs? Go to Bodeans. Want steaks? Hawksmoor. Give this place a miss, as you'll come out full but disappointed.

jY-2qs_Zg1mRic4LBXfbQQ.text: Last time I was here with a friend was the best visit ever. I had a Davey's and my friend  a Fluke. We haven't had them till now, so we enjoyed the cocktails very much. They also came at a reasonable price.

0jznFvFu5FvFmyKqJSlt-Q.text: Over priced food. Food arrived luke warm. Sides were less than adequate. Wine was good. Service ok. Views of St. Paul's were good but better from the rooftop bar. Second time eating there and wouldn't go back.

nw1pBXxAE9vRW_T8cG1H1A.text: A group of us decided to some here after reading good reviews. Unfortunately, we were all pretty disappointed.Pros: Nice decor, good appetizers, certain mains were delicious like the short ribs and the brownie dessert. However, the list ends here.Cons: Cocktails and desserts were NOT good. I asked the server for a strong bitter cocktail and I got some watered down whiskey and gin. Got a gin at the end of the evening which was also watery. The peanut butter cheesecake dessert was just mousse, mostly cream with a hint of peanut butter which is not what I call a cheesecake. My friend got what tasted like frozen yogurt but was frozen to the point where the yogurt comes off as chunks. The brownie apparently was good though. The service which wasn't that great and a bit strange. First, at the bar, my boyfriend ordered a Boulevardier which is a pretty standard drink and the server said the bartender didn't know how to make it which was rather odd (later she retracted the statement and did end up giving us the drink). During our meal, our server at the table felt the need to explain to some of us why she asked our friend to cut into his steak (it was to make sure the steak was done to his taste) which was unnecessary and irrelevant. While she explained that some of our orders were possibly mixed up because one person moved into an empty seat (in which case everyone else should have gotten their plates except that one person) but instead, our plates were all over the place and disorganized. That also wasn't a good enough reason to explain why most of our steaks were more well done than what we had ordered - the rares were medium rare, medium rares were medium and the one medium steak at the table was on the well done side. At the end of the meal when they were clearing plates, my boyfriend already told one server that he wasn't finished and maybe 5 minutes later, someone else tried to clear his plate when he clearly wasn't done.All in all, it was weird service and I most definitely would not come back. There are other places that serve good food without the confusion of services and bad cocktails and desserts.

_pXnnHHKF4Wi93F7OuE7eg.text: Barbecoa is the steakhouse created as a joint venture between Jamie Oliver and Adam Perry Lang. Frankly i would have loved to have been able to estimate the contribution of each of them to the food that is served here, but i do not have sufficient qualifications for that yet. Its located at One New Change, which is quite close to my flat as well as my office. So i knew that i would be trying it out sometime soon, and i got the chance last week. Barbecoa'a location at one of London's pre-eminent tourist spots seems to be a bit of a waste. Its pricey. I can't imagine that there would be many walk-in customers from among the foreigners visiting St Paul's.The menu is somewhat limited. I ordered chicken liver on toast as a starter. It was satisfactory. For my main course I went for the sirloin steak with mushrooms on a bed of rosemary sauce. Initially I was disappointed since I did not have the choice of the sauce (I love bearnaise ). However that feeling lasted only till the arrival of the food. It was brilliant. The steak was very well cooked and the mushrooms were tender. The sauce complemented the meat perfectly. The piece that I got had a bit of hard skin on it but that did not compromise its quality by too much. For those of you who would not want to indulge themselves with a steak, you can have something from a selection of burgers, ribs and such other meat dishes. Barbecoa has a less extensive wine list than most of its competitors (in the sense that it's wine list does not run into hundreds of pages :) ). But the selection available proved to be enough for an amateur like me. It's an expensive restaurant and the bill can easily exceed £50 per person. It would be a nice place for a professional meal for bankers working in the area. I would recommend Barbecoa to my boss as the location for our next team dinner :)

Fx2oJvQ3zciysHHM6qJinQ.text: Went here for the work Xmas meal. The place is an upmarket BBQ /grill restaurant. American themed with some British influences. (Owners are Jamie Oliver & Adam Perry Lang).Great view of St Pauls - so a good place to take cashed up tourists!Great drinks menu(Margarita's were divine!) The choice of starters is pretty diverse, the chicken liver was to die for! Pork scratching was nice and the bread basket had a nice mix of different cuts of bread. I thought the olives were overpriced (£4 for a few large green olives over ice).Oh, the chips are cooked in duck fat! Yummo! (pretty filling & rich though).All the mains looked nice, I had the Pit Beef which was gorgeous! The pulled pork was pretty good too! The portions don't look big but they are all pretty filling...(I took half my main home!).Overall,  a good place to go to if you are after a nice BBQ fix.I hope to see a trend of more places like it in London but at more reasonable prices.

hiVnbGs7q3-28cAsHvlHCQ.text: Barbacoa is a trendy new grill house by Jamie Oliver and Adam Perry Lang.  The décor was very nice but I didn't think there was anything special about the food.  It was a good quality but slightly on the pricey side.

vHNDYEc4daLoL3KVHLfj3g.text: Perfection. Our experience was beginning-to-end nothing but satisfaction each and every bite. We have been dining in all kinds and classes of restaurants for years, way before Yelping about it, and usually those fancy "branded" celebrity-buzzed ones were always a plain overpriced mini-sized collection of dishes. Not this one! The starters were just right and refreshing, the meat was done to perfection pink medium fillets, and the dessert was a food finish to an awesome meal. Service and ambiance were great. Yes we paid a lot. But it was worth every dime.

FpeEQnZvhq207OhcJMc_vA.text: Four stars may be a touch generous but it is based on receiving especially kind service. A waitress provided my daughter with crayons and paper and added an evenings worth of playful, though not intrusive, entertainment. As for the food, overall, it was very good. The one significant disappointment was the short rib, although it was perfectly cooked , good quality meat and fall off the bone tender, the flavour was a bit lacking - a side sauce would have been a welcome addition. I tried to add some flavour by piling on cole slaw - not ideal, but better then the alternative. We started with the perfectly fried and tender calamari which was served on a bed of guacamole - excellent - and the baby back ribs - excellent as well with a touch of spice from slivers of red and green jalapeños. We also had the ceviche which was very good - light and refreshing. In addition to the short rib, we had the pulled pork - with a delicious BBQ sauce and a smoky flavour(was liquid smoke used?). We also had the duck fat fries - which were okay. For dessert we had a deconstructed lemon meringue pie - eh. My daughter enjoyed her white chocolate and dark chocolate ice cream (with a special treat - thank you kind waitress).Overall a very good meal and the view of St Paul's was spectacular. The clubby vibe was fine - very different from the vibe at Daisy Mae's in NYC  - Adam Lang Perry's other restaurant, but they are very different restaurants. I have heard that the burger is very good and I will try it next time(if there is a next time). By the way, for all the food described above as well as 4 bottles of beer the cost was about 125 - a bit spendey.

5i3ApR8R7uaVT9qMOvroOw.text: An American Yelping in London says this is as good a barbecue place as you're likely to find in London, and a HELL of a restaurant otherwise.  In the span of a week, I ate here twice.  Make reservations.For my foodies, take everything trending in dining within the past 2 years: locally-sourced food, pork, comfort food, barbecue, stunning cocktails lovingly prepared and a dreamboat BEER and wine list.  Barbecoa has it all.  Right down to the butcher shop downstairs that supplies their meats.First off, as a man who has probably eaten my bodyweight in chicken wings, let me say that the "hot wings" here are the best wings I've ever had in my life.  They're not hot in the very least.  But they somehow taste like barbecued bacon.  They are incredible.  I even ate the watercress on the plate.For my first main, I had the pulled pork.  It was outstanding.  A bit fancified to be real Carolina-style, but excellent nonetheless.  I started my drinks with a local beer.  For dessert, I ordered the Barbecoa Blazer.  This hot bourbon concoction was set on fire and mixed at the table.  I will spend the rest of my life trying to replicate it.  Do yourself a favor and order one.Then for "second dessert" I tried one of their Gin drinks called the Bramble.  Also excellent, but nothing can top that Blazer.Fast-forward to the next visit. We couldn't get a table before 9:30.  We ended up waiting until 10, and in that span were brought a bottle of prosecco, the house-cured olives, and the pork cracklins (there's a different name, but they're essentially pork rinds).  They really tout these on their bar snacks menu, but I didn't care for either very much.  When we got to the table, I ordered three plates of the chicken wings (for the 6 of us) they were gone in a flash.They had a tri-tip steak special, so I ordered that.  It was good but not great.  Great was the gigantic beef short rib the rest of the table enjoyed.  I drank a Maple Treacle as an opener.  Also excellent, then we moved on to a round of Blazers for the table.  Ambience is very modern.  low cozy large booths, giant  "birdcages" or small tables. Stunning light fixtures.  Service is excellent.  I will find any excuse to get back to London to get there.
